context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Hack attack that took internet offline was about extortion and revenge
context_meta.summary: Last year, hackers used a network of hundreds of thousands of hijacked devices to take major portions of the internet offline for hours. The Mirai botnet, as it's called, conscripted routers, smart fridges, and CCTV cameras to take down vital services that power companies like PayPal and Netflix. New Jersey man Paras Jha pleaded guilty today to computer crimes charges, court filings show. The guilty plea also reveals Jha's motivation for the attack, and it's less exotic than you might think. According to the guilty plea, Jha's attack was all about two things: revenge, and money. Jha and his two co-conspirators, Dalton Norman and Josiah White, ran a firm called Protraf Solutions LLC, which offered protection against the kind of DDOS attack that the Mirai botnet caused. It was a classic extortion scam: Cause a DDOS attack against the company, and then make it all go away when they pay up. One of the targets of the Mirai botnet was Dyn, an internet infrastructure company that provides services to companies like Netflix and PayPal. When Dyn was hit with an attack, it caused the massive internet outage that affected millions worldwide. But the crimes didn't just stop at extortion. The group also used their botnet to conduct "click fraud," registering fake pageviews on website that advertisers pay for. The plea claims that the group made $180,000 from the fraud. But Jha's DDOS attacks weren't just limited to extortion. The complaint also details how he used the Mirai botnet to attack criminal competitors: In August 2016, defendant PARAS JHA engaged in a feud with rival DDOS botnet operators, during which period JHA generated and sent fraudulent abuse complaints to hosting providers associated with the rival group. JHA also conspired to conduct DDOS attacks against Internet architecture associated with this group. JHA further participated in a Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) hijacking scheme in which JHA and co-conspirators fraudulently gained control over IP addresses that were in legitimate use by third parties. JHA conducted these activities to consolidate and maximize the power of the Mirai botnet. So next time you blame a massive internet outage on technical screw-ups or North Korea, just remember: Normally, it's three guys in a basement with a bone to pick.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Star Wars: The Last Jedi spoilers – the big questions, answered
context_meta.summary: Warning: contains major spoilers Have you seen Star Wars: The Last Jedi? If you haven’t, this spoiler-filled article probably isn’t going to be for you (and trust us: Episode Eight boasts some jaw-droppingly good moments, all ripe for spoiling). But if you’re up to date with the latest events in a galaxy far, far away, here’s a quick round up of some of the big questions Rian Johnson’s film has left us with.  1. What's happened to the Force? Have the rules completely changed?  It’s not so much a case of rules being broken, and more a case of existing expectations being blown apart and pre-established boundaries challenged. But either way, in The Last Jedi Johnson is clearly having a blast with the idea of what the Force can and can’t do. There’s a raw physicality to those bridging scenes between Rey and Kylo Ren, for instance, that transcends traditional Force telepathy: a sense of “crossing over”, opening a window and really reaching through. True, we later learn that the intense bond between the pair has been engineered by Snoke for his own purposes (and it’s not clear exactly how he does this). Without getting too metaphysical, it’s also worth noting that all physical sensations arguably take place in the mind: Rey and Kylo might feel as if they’re being touched, or remotely attacked, without these actions really taking place. But the fact remains that The Force, in this film, feels more potent, more unexpected – and, given these new developments, more viscerally frightening – than ever before. 2. How can Luke suddenly have the power of astral projection? Well, possibly not anymore, as Luke is now pretty definitely dead (see question nine). But his extended projection scene in The Last Jedi was another example of the way Johnson has pushed his definition of Force powers to the limit, showing us things we’ve never before seen in a Star Wars movie. Interestingly, there is some precedent for these kind of powers in some of the (non-canon) Star Wars comic books. In the series Dark Empire, for instance, Luke is able to create a projected double of himself and use it to fool others – and, in other stories, it’s established that a kind of astral projection can be used by certain Jedi and Sith, although not that often. But Johnson’s decision to kill Luke off immediately after his ruse – implying that the effort involved has taken all his strength – suggests that Luke’s extended accomplishment, in the world of the films, may have been a one-off, never-before-attempted feat. Star Wars | More from The Telegraph 3. Just how powerful is Leia? We already know, from previous films, that Leia “has the Force” (You have that power too,” Luke tells her in Return of the Jedi. “In time you’ll learn to use it”). And yet, because it’s something we’ve not really seen in any detail on the big-screen before, the scene in which the General guides herself back to the safety of her ship, evading an icy death in space, feels incredibly important. Carrie Fisher as Leia Sadly, while we’d normally be speculating about whether we’d be seeing more of Leia’s powers in Episode Nine, the untimely death of Carrie Fisher last year means that this now feels unlikely. Lucasfilm has promised that a resurrected CGI Leia definitely isn’t on the cards – and plans to focus on the character in the final film will have been adjusted accordingly. 4. Are Rey’s parents really “nobodies”? The revelation that Rey’s parents were a pair of heartless nobodies, who callously sold their daughter then met their deaths shortly afterwards, was one of the film’s most brilliantly subversive twists. It’s possible that Kylo may have been lying to Rey, attempting to manipulate her into joining him – but his revelation that she really did come from nothing had a ring of truth to it. Furthermore, in a franchise that has previously traded on secret identities and mystery fathers, the concept that Rey is special just because she’s Rey – and not because she’s so-and-so’s daughter – feels oddly affirming. Daisy Ridley as Rey Rey doesn’t need to have a hidden, “chosen one” heritage – she’s powerful and important in her own right, because of her strength, and her courage, and her resolution. Our private guess, for what it’s worth, is that Kylo was only half-lying: we reckon it’ll turn out that Rey’s parents were indeed nobodies – but quite nice ones, who always intended to come back for their daughter. This way, she’ll still get some bittersweet emotional resolution, without compromising the important message that a “nobody” can still be a Force-wielding force to be reckoned with. 5. What was going on with that Rey “hall of mirrors” scene? Honestly? Your guess here is as good as ours. Our pet interpretation, however, is that the trippy sequence is related to Rey’s driving desire to identify and track down her parents. She keeps searching for them, desperately trying to find out who she “really” is – but the true answer, as evidenced by the endless repetitions of her own face, is that Rey is, and always has been, herself. Her background, she needs to accept, is nowhere near as important as her future – and finding her parents isn’t the same thing as finding herself. This explanation, if correct, would fit in well with Kylo’s revelation about how Rey’s parents really were “nobodies”. As per above, we’re inclined to believe at least part of this statement, although it’s still worth taking with a grain of salt. (Kylo could have been lying to manipulate Rey – or may even have had his mind/visions influenced by Snoke.) 6. Who, exactly, was Snoke? And does it matter? And what, we might add, was going on with that gold dressing gown? Terrible look, Snoke. You’re much more intimidating as a giant hologram. In retrospect, of course, the decision to make the Supreme Leader seem weaker – shrunken, and somehow substantially diminished in grandeur and menace – in this film was probably all part of Johnson’s plan, building up as it does to the moment in which the former arch-villain makes a fatal miscalculation. Now that he’s been neatly sliced in two, however, all the feverish speculation about his “real” identity” that fans were previously indulging in feels a bit pointless. Andy Serkis as Snoke We imagine the story of Snoke’s past might be explored, someday, in a Star Wars spin-off title. But now that he’s out of the picture, it feels highly unlikely that his background will form a major plot point in Episode Nine – or that a big, game-changing reveal was ever on the cards. Snoke, safe to say, is nobody’s daddy. 7. Are Hux’s days numbered? Ah, poor Hux. Conflicted Kylo might flicker between evil and good, but his space Nazi buddy has always been properly committed to the Dark Side. And yet, despite his appropriately villainous voice and looks – and infantile lack of temper tantrums – Hux is now stuck playing second fiddle to Kylo, simmering with resentment while the new Supreme Leader throws out ridiculous, emotionally impulsive orders. Domhnall Gleeson as Hux His barely disguised loathing – and Kylo’s rampant instability – mean that Hux will probably make a new bid for power and meet his end early on in Episode Nine. We hope, for his sake, he gets to blow up a few planets or something first. 8. Could Rey and Kylo Ren end up switching roles? All this barely concealed Force-flirting and reluctant emotional bonding can’t end well, can it? They might share a mysterious connection, but now that Kylo has apparently chosen his path, it feels unlikely that the series has a happy ending in store for him and Rey. The rogue Solo son, furthermore, is also now the main villain of the piece (sorry Hux), meaning that any redemption arc would have to take place pretty late in the game, or risk taking away all the stakes. Adam Driver as Kylo Ren One just-about-plausible twist is that Episode Nine will see Rey explore her own dark side and turn antagonist – something which was strongly hinted at in her Last Jedi scenes with Luke, in which he sensed her terrifying potential for darkness. Overall, however, it feels as if the franchise, under Johnson’s direction, could be more interested in the idea of finding balance, and carving out a world where the light and dark extremes of the Force must both take backseat. The emergence of a new generation of Force-sensitive characters (as evidenced by that final scene with the little boy) could also play into this. 9. Was there a subtle “let’s be nicer to animals” message at play? If so, it’s a message we’re thoroughly on board with. We had Chewbacca getting guilt-tripped by a sad porg while eating a roasted porg – I mean really, Chewie: how could you? – and some surprisingly sympathetic, intelligent-seeming ice crystal foxes, on hand to help the rebellion out of a tight spot. Chewbacca and a porg There was even an apparent anti- animal racing sub plot, courtesy of the casino scenes (take home lesson: whipping things and making them race each other is mean, no matter how glamorous or fun it might look at first). That said, when it comes to sheer pathos, nothing will ever rival the grieving Rancor keeper. 10. Is Luke definitely dead? Will he come back as a Force ghost in Episode Nine? We’re going to go out on a limb here and say yes and yes. Body disappearing under a cloak like that? Classic Jedi-who-will-probably-be-a-ghost-death. In case you’re wondering, the standard Star Wars explanation for the ghosts is that certain Jedi, such as Yoda and Obi Wan, have mastered the art of becoming one with the Force at death, while simultaneously maintaining their individuality. Mark Hamill as Luke Skywalker Previous films and materials suggested that doing this was something that had to be taught – but, during his years of self-imposed solitude, it’s perfectly plausible that Luke may have come across the technique, or even been schooled in it by ghost-Yoda. Without being too cynical, it also feels likely that Episode Nine will want to maintain a link to at least one of the three veteran actors from the original trilogy. With Harrison Ford’s Han Solo meeting his end in The Force Awakens, and Carrie Fisher tragically passing away in 2016, a future Luke ghost cameo feels like a fairly safe bet. 11. ​Have the “rules” for Force ghosts changed? In previous Star Wars movies, Force ghosts haven’t really been able to do that much. They can turn up to Ewok parties, yes – but interacting with the real world (or grabbing a slice of barbecued Stormtrooper) always appeared to be out of the question. In The last Jedi, however, Yoda appears to have physical form; he was able to start a fire, gleefully burn some ancient Jedi texts and actively engage with Luke’s surroundings. All suggesting that Johnson may have chosen to shake things up a bit, or at least test the rules surrounding the ghosts and their physicality.  12. How will Leia now feature in Episode Nine? Lucasfilm have promised us that a movie starring a computer-generated General definitely isn’t on the cards, but we don’t yet know exactly how Episode Nine will handle Carrie Fisher’s untimely death and departure from the series. Her emotional, beautifully understated reunion with Luke was one of the stand-out moments of The Last Jedi, and ensured that the franchise was at least able to provide proper closure for the siblings. But while it was previously suggested that the final part of the new trilogy would focus heavily on Leia, it now seems probable that Episode Nine will choose to deploy the character off-screen, while still ensuring that her presence will be felt in the movie. Logistically, this could pose quite a challenge: the film will presumably need to show what the remaining rebels are up to without ever directly depicting their leader. 60 Star Wars characters, ranked from worst to best Perhaps the most pressing story question, however, is exactly what Leia’s physical absence from the movie will mean for Kylo Ren, who found himself unable to directly kill his mother in The Last Jedi, despite having a clear chance to do so. The moment felt as if it could be foreshadowing a future confrontation scene, in which Leia would come face to face with her turned son. This now feels unlikely, but it is just about conceivable that a remote reunion between Leia and Kylo that relies on their voices alone could still take place (perhaps via another Force connection). A CGI Fisher would doubtless feel strange and disrespectful – but a digital manipulation of existing audio recordings would possibly pass muster with fans. Another option, of course, is that the filmmakers will simply choose to kill Leia off-screen, revealing her death in the opening scroll. To us, though, the convenience of this feels a little cheap and, consequently, not very probable.

Animal shelters typically don't have enough staff members to provide the necessary bottle feeding for motherless animals less than 5 weeks old, said Lori Whitney, the organization' public affairs and adoption coordinator. Bangladeshi immigrant Akayed Ullah, 27, followed those instructions on Monday when he tried to set off a homemade bomb in one of New York's busiest commuter hubs, in an attack that illustrates the difficulty of stopping "do-it-yourself" attacks by radicals who act alone. "They tend to be less organized and less deadly," said Seamus Hughes, a former adviser at the U.S. government's National Counterterrorism Center.

Putin, whom critics have accused of using state TV, the courts and the police to demonise and marginalise the liberal opposition, said earlier this month he would run for re-election in March 2018 - a contest he seems sure to win comfortably and extend his grip on power into a third decade. The ruling United Russia party has traditionally backed Putin and is likely to do so again this time, but Putin clearly wants to generate a higher turnout by styling himself as someone who is above the often grubby fray of Russian party politics.

context_meta.title: You get more out of giving a gift if you don't expect anything in return, say SFU researchers
context_meta.summary: A new study from Simon Fraser University (SFU) suggests that you get more out of giving a gift, if you don't expect anything in return. SFU psychology PhD student Dylan Wiwad said that there are benefits to giving “selfishly” — like when you buy pizza for someone who helps you move — but it's even better with no further expectations. “Sometimes giving for selfish reasons can backfire, so to speak, in terms of our own our own well-being,” Wiwad said. “It's just not as beneficial.” Wiwad said he hopes to do another study that looks at the actual act of giving, but there are challenges that need to be addressed first. “It's really hard to tell somebody, 'go and give for this reason,'” Wiwad said.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: HTC Vive Tracker review: A new way to experience virtual reality
context_meta.summary: The promise of virtual reality has always been to escape the bounds of your living room or office and enjoy an entirely new world where the same rules don't apply. High-end VR headsets like the HTC Vive have largely delivered on that promise, but if you've ever dabbled in VR you'll know that sometimes you wish you could bring real-world objects with you into the digital realm. HTC's new Vive Tracker promises to allow you to do just that, and I've taken it — and a handful of the compatible accessories — for a spin. Just to get it out of the way, I'll say that I already think the HTC Vive should be your default choice for a virtual reality headset, period. The games, compatibility, support, and hardware quality are simply better than the competition. Having played with both the Vive and Oculus for more hours than I wish to admit, I can safely say the Vive's room-scale VR is the most immersive virtual reality experience available today. With that in mind, adding some funky smart trackers to mix should just be icing on the cake, right? Well, the short answer is "yes," but the longer answer is a bit more nuanced. I went hands-on with a pair of Vive Trackers, Hyperkin's new "Hyper Blaster" which is a Nintendo light gun lookalike, some Tracker-compatible wrist straps, and both the Paddle handle and Racket handle for various sports titles. All three peripherals have built-in mounts for the Vive Tracker, and installing the tracker — which looks like a little black crown — takes about ten seconds. The idea here is that when playing a game that supports these accessories, you'll use them in place of the standard Vive controllers. Because these tracker peripherals are so specialized for the games they are designed to work with, the experience should be that much more immersive. The trackers themselves are simple gadgets, with a single button and a microUSB charging port. They last for between four and five hours of play time per charge, which is more than enough for a few play sessions before needing to be plugged in. Just like the standard Vive controllers and the headset, the Vive Trackers are detected by the Vive Base Stations and tracked in real time. But what makes them particularly powerful is their ability to relay control commands to the games you play via whatever accessory you have them plugged into. For example, the Hyper Blaster actually has several hardware buttons built into it, as well as a tactile trigger. The Tracker interfaces with the plastic pistol through a port that automatically connects when you attached the two together, and when you pull the trigger or press a button, that input is registered by the Vive. This allows accessories like the Hyper Blaster to work seamlessly with the Vive without any built-in electronics or even a battery; it's all handled by the Tracker. I played a few different games with the Hyper Blaster, including the lighthearted Duck Season and Operation Warcade. With the Tracker equipped, Hyperkin's handgun worked flawlessly. It responded instantly to all input and felt as though it were a standalone controller connected directly to the Vive itself. If you've ever used the Vive and a Vive controller before, you know how important the feeling of zero latency is when manipulating objects in VR, and the Vive Tracker paired with the Hyper Blaster felt perfect. When I'm in the mood for VR, I do tend to play a lot of shooters, and I could easily see the Hyper Blaster becoming my new go-to controller in games that support it (there are already quite a few). That's not to say the standard Vive controllers don't do a good job, but they're more general purpose inputs, and Hyperkin's little pistol feels really, really nice. Next, I tried out the sports accessories, along with a few of the games that support them. I tested the racket and paddle on Virtual Sports and Eleven: Table Tennis VR, respectively, and then spent some time with near-full-body VR tracking — with Trackers strapped to my feet and Vive controllers in both hands — so that I could embarrass myself in Final Soccer VR. Both the racket and paddle are surprisingly well-made, with thick, heavy plastic and rubberized grips around the handles. At first I was afraid they'd be akin to the cheap plastic peripherals that everyone with a Nintendo Wii seemed to have a dozen of, but thankfully that's not the case. They're sturdy and strong, and the tracker responded great when I was using them in VR. Unlike the Hyper Blaster, they don't have any built-in buttons, so you'll need to keep a Vive controller nearby to navigate menus and the like.  I don't play a lot of sports in VR, but if you're really into that sort of thing I could easily see someone really falling in love with them. The wrist (or leg) bands are called Track Straps, and are from a company called Rebuff Reality. You just screw the tracker right onto them and strap them on whichever limb you need to track, depending on the game. For Final Soccer VR, you can use them on your hands (as a goalie) or feet for kicking, and then just hold the standard Vive controllers for hand movement. They're obviously incredibly simple accessories, but they work reasonably well for their intended purpose. I will say that, unlike having a tracker attached to a rigid peripheral like a gun or racket, tracking something like a foot is a bit more sketchy. Sometimes it would feel like my virtual foot wasn't a perfect 1:1 with my real foot, but that's because the tracker can really only tell the Vive where it, itself, is, and attempt to guess the position and orientation of the foot it is attached to. It's an interesting attempt at full-body tracking, and I think it'll continue to get better as developers spend more time with it, but don't expect perfection right out of the gate. As for the cost, here's how the Tracker and various bundles break down: One standalone tracker for $99.99 Tracker + Hyper Blaster (includes Duck Season) for $149.99 Tracker + Rackets (includes Virtual Sports) for $149.99 Racket Set (no Tracker included) for $79.99 Vive System + Tracker + Rackets set (includes Virtual Sports) for $748.99 Pair of Track Straps (includes Redfoot Bluefoot Dancing) for $24.99 The Vive Tracker (and obviously the bundles above) will begin shipping this month. If you're already a VR early adopter, you probably already know whether you want to spend the additional time (and money) to make your experience even better. I only got to test the Tracker on a handful of games, but lots of games on Steam already support it in various ways, so you probably won't have to look far to find a reason to pick one up for yourself.

context_meta.summary: An adaptation of Laker superstar Kobe Bryant's farewell poem to the sport he loved, "Dear Basketball" (USA) stands out as the most beautifully animated film in the show. Disney veteran Glen Keane's vigorous pencil drawings turn Bryant's body into a moving sculpture, soaring through the air toward the basket. Touching scenes that juxtapose an 8-year-old Bryant and the adult athlete performing the same moves show that the child truly was the father of this man. "Dear Basketball" won the World Animation Celebration in September and is a likely nominee for the Oscar for animated short.

Edward Saatchi, executive producer of the VR project, said in an interview with GamesBeat that the story will be told in three chapters, with the first one debuting at the Sundance Film Festival in January. Wolves in the Walls was about 60 percent done when the Oculus Story Studio folded, but Facebook said it would continue to fund VR storytelling projects through third-party relationships, and in this case, Oculus provided the funding to complete Wolves in the Walls.

context_meta.title: Firefighters fear more winds in battle against wildfires
context_meta.summary: California firefighting crews may face on Thursday another round of fierce gusts that have fed a volatile wildfire, one of the largest in the state's history, as they protect homes from flames and build control lines. The so-called Thomas Fire, already the state's fifth-largest blaze of its kind on record, threatened the communities of Santa Barbara, Carpinteria, Summerland and Montecito early on Thursday after destroying more than 700 homes since it began on Dec. 4, fire officials said. “Firefighters will remain engaged in structure defense operations and scout for opportunities to establish direct perimeter control,” the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection said in a statement, noting that the fire threatened 18,000 structures. Gusty Santa Ana winds were forecast to whip up to 50 mph early in the morning and peak during the day before decreasing by evening, while warm temperatures and single-digit relative humidity persist, the National Weather Service said in an advisory.
